8383.Definicao: A substance in your blood that reacts with a foreign invader such as a germ or something you’re allergic to (allergen). In some cases, you develop antibodies when you have an infection so you are less likely to have it again.

8384.Definicao: If you've got an allergy, antihistamines can help to stop a bad reaction. They're usually tablets but sometimes you might be given a syrup, because it is easier to swallow. You can also get antihistamine cream that you put on your skin.

8385.Definicao: A condition where you stop breathing – usually only for a few seconds. Some people have apnoea only when they’re asleep.

8386.Definicao: A little tube attached to your large intestine that has no function at all! It’s about 9cm long in adults and doesn’t usually cause any problems, unless it becomes infected – which is called appendicitis.

8387.Definicao: Our bodies contain lots of blood, which moves around in arteries, veins and capillaries. Arteries carry blood away from the heart to the rest of your body. They are made up of different layers in a tube.

8388.Definicao: A type of pain relief that usually comes in tablets. Aspirin can be dangerous for children under 16 years old, so you should only ever take it if your doctor prescribes it.

8389.Definicao: A condition where you feel breathless and wheeze a lot. It’s caused by the passages in your lungs becoming inflamed, but it can be treated using drugs which open up these passages (bronchodilators).

8390.Definicao: This is a nasty infection you can get between your toes that is caused by a fungus. It’s very contagious so make sure you don’t walk around in bare feet when you’ve got it, and don’t share your shoes with anyone either. It can be treated using creams from your chemist.

8391.Definicao: This means that a passage or canal in the body is closed up at one end instead of being like a tube. There's lots of different types of atresia, which all happened while the baby was developing in the womb.

8392.Definicao: One of the chambers in the heart.

8393.Definicao: This is a kind of disease where the body gets confused and starts attacking itself because it thinks it’s dangerous. For instance, in arthritis, the body identifies the tissue in the joints as being ‘the enemy’ and so attacks them causing damage.

8394.Definicao: A type of germ or bug which can make you ill. They’re treated using antibiotics.

8395.Definicao: This is a substance that shows up well on x-rays. It can either be swallowed or put up your bottom so the doctor can see your digestive system and check for any abnormalities.

8396.Definicao: Something that is slow-growing or won’t spread anywhere else. You can get benign tumours, which won’t spread throughout the body, for instance.

8397.Definicao: This is a mark on your skin that is there when you are born or develops very soon afterwards. They can be brown, red or even a blue colour.

8398.Definicao: A test on a sample of blood that counts how many of each type of blood cell is present. It’s used as a general check that you are well or not.

8399.Definicao: A test that shows the amount of certain gases, like oxygen and carbon dioxide, are in your blood. It’s usually used to check whether you’re breathing effectively and getting enough oxygen.

8400.Definicao: There are lots of different blood groups – A, B, AB and O – and everyone has one. Blood groups are important if you’re having a blood transfusion, as certain blood groups won’t be accepted if you have a different one to the donated blood.

8401.Definicao: Blood pressure shows how hard your heart is working to move blood around your body. When the doctor puts an arm-band around one of your arms and starts pumping air into it, they're checking your blood pressure.

8402.Definicao: This means the amount of glucose (a form of sugar/carbohydrate) in blood.

8403.Definicao: A way of replacing blood lost during an operation or after an accident. Before you have a blood transfusion, you’ll have your blood group checked to make sure your body will accept the transfusion.

8404.Definicao: This is a normal reaction to being embarrassed, or sometimes scared. The tiny blood vessels in your cheeks swell to let more blood through, which is what makes you go red.

8405.Definicao: These are the two tubes that connect the bottom of your windpipe to your lungs.

8406.Definicao: A type of drug used if you have asthma. They work by opening up the passages in your lungs so you can breathe easier. You usually take them using an inhaler or ‘puffer’.

8407.Definicao: A type of birthmark which is the colour of milky coffee, hence the name.

8408.Definicao: A group of diseases that are caused by cells forming in an uncontrolled way. There are lots of different types of cancer – some are easier to treat than others and some affect children more than adults. Research has meant that cancer is much more treatable than it was thirty years ago.

8409.Definicao: A cannula is an extremely thin plastic tube that is put into a vein to give medicines or fluids or take sample of blood.

8410.Definicao: These are the smallest blood vessel – most of them are only big enough to allow a red blood cell through.

8411.Definicao: A group of substances found in food that the body converts into energy. Food containing carbohydrates include starchy foods such as potatoes, rice, pasta and bread.

8412.Definicao: A gas, which we breathe out into the atmosphere. Its chemical symbol is CO2

8413.Definicao: This is just another word for the heart.

8414.Definicao: Having a cast on a broken bone will hold it in one position so it heals right. Casts can be made from a lot of different materials, including plaster, fibreglass, plastic and even air. When your bones are better, the doctor will remove your cast, but don't worry, it doesn't hurt.

8415.Definicao: This consists of your brain and spinal cord and is referred to as the CNS for short.

8416.Definicao: A group of disorders where a person’s brain is damaged in during childbirth or early childhoodoften by not receiving enough oxygen. This means that the person may have stiff muscles, jerky movements and problems with co-ordination. They may also have speech problems.

8417.Definicao: This is the fluid that surrounds the brain and spinal cordand and acts as a cushion. It’s often called CSF.

8418.Definicao: Also known as a pharmacist – this is the person who can advise you on medicines and supplies them to you either with or without a prescription.

8419.Definicao: An infectious disease that makes you break out in tiny blisters which then form scabs. These blisters are often very itchy and it can be difficult not to scratch them. When you have chicken pox you should stay away from people with low immune systems as chicken pox can cause quite severe problems for them.

8420.Definicao: The medical word for your collarbone – the ridge you can feel from your shoulders to in front of your neck.

8421.Definicao: This is where a baby is born with a vertical split in their lip. It can affect one side of the lip or both. It happened while the baby was developing in the womb and can be fixed in an operation. Sometimes a baby can have both a cleft lip and a cleft palate.

8422.Definicao: This is where a baby is born with a split in the roof of their mouth. It happened while the baby was developing in the womb and can be fixed in an operation. Sometimes a baby can have both a cleft lip and a cleft palate.

8423.Definicao: The four lowest vertebras in your back and they’re the leftovers from our tails before we developed into humans!

8424.Definicao: The bit of the inner ear that turns sounds into nerve messages which travel to the brain.

8425.Definicao: A piece of equipment for helping someone who is severely deaf to hear sounds and understand speech although it will always sound a bit different.

8426.Definicao: A cold is a type of viral infection that causes a runny nose and a sore throat. There’s no cure for a cold, but you can take medicines for the symptoms.

8427.Definicao: This is caused by the herpes virus, and makes a sore spot around your mouth that can weep pus and then scab over. They’re quite catching – so don’t kiss anyone with a cold sore, because you might catch one too!

8428.Definicao: A pouch which is used to collect poo from a stoma (an opening made by a doctor) in a patient who is no longer able to poo naturally.

8429.Definicao: Congenital means ‘present at birth’, that you have a problem or illness from the time you were born.

8430.Definicao: The legal term for when you agree to something happening.

8431.Definicao: A consultant is a senior doctor who has had lots of training and has extra knowledge about one type of illness or treatment.

8432.Definicao: If you're contagious, it means that anyone around you can catch your illness. This is more common than you might think - colds are contagious, because you can catch them from someone else.

8433.Definicao: A disease that affects the lungs and intestines, by clogging them up with heavy sticky stuff called mucus. People with cystic fibrosis have to have regular physiotherapy to get the mucus out of their lungs and also have to take lots of tablets each day.

8434.Definicao: If you come in for a test or an operation and go home the same day, you’ve had day surgery. More and more tests and operations are done like this as you’re more likely to get better quickly when you’re at home with your family.

8435.Definicao: When the body stops working completely – the person has died. This means that the heart has stopped, the person is not breathing anymore and the brain has switched off.

8436.Definicao: If you don't have enough water in your body, you can feel very unwell. When you sweat, you lose water and it's easy to get dehydrated when it's hot, so you need to drink plenty of water. You can also lose a lot of water when you’re sick with diarrhoea and vomiting.

8437.Definicao: A person who is trained to look after your teeth and gums and fix any problems if they occur. There are also dentists who specialise in fitting braces to straighten teeth.

8438.Definicao: This is the condition where the amount of glucose in the blood is too high.

8439.Definicao: When you’ve got diarrhoea, you’ll have very runny poo and will need to go to the toilet a lot. Remember to drink lots of fluids – this will stop you feeling worse.

8440.Definicao: The study of how what we eat can affect our health. Dietitians are the people who check what we eat and suggest ways of improving our diet so we can feel healthier. They also make up special diets for people with diseases that affect their eating.

8441.Definicao: This consists of your oesophagus, stomach, duodenum, small bowel, large bowel, and rectum. Its job is to break down the food you eat so the goodness can be absorbed and get rid of the waste stuff as poo.

8442.Definicao: This is what you hear through. There are three bits to your ear – the outside bit which you can see, the middle bit which is the passage from your ear hole to your ear drum and then the inner bit which is where sounds are turned into nerve messages for your brain.

8443.Definicao: This is often a sign of infection, but it may not be your ears that are infected. Sometimes when you have a sore throat, you also get earache too.

8444.Definicao: This is a condition that affects a person’s eating behaviour and is damaging to a person’s physical and mental wellbeing. The most common kinds of eating disorder are Anorexia Nervosa and Bulimia.

8445.Definicao: This is short for Echocardiogram and it uses sound waves to show a picture of your heart and how it is beating. It also shows how blood is flowing through your heart.

8446.Definicao: A physical reaction to a sudden burst of extra electrical activity in the brain. The type of seizure that a person has depends on where in the brain this activity happens.

8447.Definicao: The medical word for poo. Once all the water and goodness has been absorbed from what you eat, faeces is all that’s left.

8448.Definicao: The diagnosis often given to babies and children who are not getting enough nutrition from their food. This could be due to not eating enough or in some cases, to the goodness in food not being absorbed properly by the intestines.

8449.Definicao: Temporary loss of consciousness due to a lack of oxygen in the brain. If you feel faint, you should sit down and lean forwards, with your head between your knees. This will encourage blood to flow towards your brain.

8450.Definicao: A baby developing in the womb. Before the eighth week, the baby is called an embryo. While the baby is developing in the womb, it will grow from about 2.5cm long to a final length of 51cm long.

8451.Definicao: The name for a device that holds together a bone by pins that are inserted through the skin into the bone and held in place by a surrounding brace. It can help a broken bone to heal correctly but can also be used to lengthen a bone by gradually pulling the cut ends of the bone apart so that new bone forms in the gap.

8452.Definicao: Freckles are just small patches of skin containing melanin or pigment, the substance that gives us colour. Freckles usually appear when you’re out in the sun. People with fair or red hair tend to have more freckles than dark haired people, and so should take care not to burn by using a sun block cream.

8453.Definicao: The name of a medication that sends a patient to sleep and stops them feeling pain during a surgical procedure by blocking signals from nerves to the brain.

8454.Definicao: Germs cause diseases. There are different types of germ, including viruses and bacteria.

8455.Definicao: The medical word for your gums.

8456.Definicao: This is a really common illness in children. Fluid builds up inside the middle ear and goes sticky like glue. This stops the little bones in the ear from moving about which makes it difficult to hear. It usually clears up on its own, but you may need a small drainage tube put into your eardrum called a grommet.

8457.Definicao: This is a small drainage tube that is used to treat glue ear.

8458.Definicao: Your gums are what hold your teeth in place. They fit tightly around the base of each tooth to stop germs getting inside your jaw. Healthy gums are usually a light pink or brown colour, but if your gums bleed a lot when you brush your teeth, this could be a sign of gum disease.

8459.Definicao: If a word begins with ‘haem’ this usually means that it is something to do with blood. For example, haematology is the study of blood.

8460.Definicao: If you have blood in your wee, the doctors may say that you have haematuria. It’s usually caused by an infection in your urinary system. Sometimes, the amount of blood is so small, that you can only see it under a microscope.

8461.Definicao: This is what makes red blood cells red. It’s a kind of pigment that carries the oxygen to all parts of your body. Each red blood cell contains about 350 million haemoglobin molecules!

8462.Definicao: This is a collection of blood outside of a blood vessel. One of the most common forms of hematoma is bruising on the skin.

8463.Definicao: This means 'half' as in hemi-nephrectomy – an operation where half of your kidney is removed.

8464.Definicao: A Holter monitor is a portable device that monitors the electrical activity in your heart over a 24-hour period. It involves putting stickers on your chest that link up to a recording device. This then monitors your heart rate, the shape of the complexes (in other words how each beat of your heart looks) and gives a very clear picture about how your heart rhythm is working.

8465.Definicao: These are chemical messengers that switch on and off processes in the body. For instance, starting puberty or producing more urine.

8466.Definicao: When this starts a word, it means ‘too much’ of something.

8467.Definicao: When this starts a word, it means ‘too little’ of something.

8468.Definicao: The final and longest section of the small intestine that absorbs goodness from what we eat and drink. It is attached to the colon.

8469.Definicao: All the injections you’re given when you’re growing up are designed to protect you against diseases. It’s important that you have all your immunisations at the right time. Some of them are given as a series of injections, where you have one when you’re a baby and then others as ‘boosters’.

8470.Definicao: The term used to describe somebody who cannot control the release of urine or poo from their body.

8471.Definicao: Being able to breathe is very important but asthma can sometimes make it more difficult. If you have asthma, running about or eating certain foods can irritate your airways and make it harder for you to breathe. An inhaler is a special gadget that sprays medicine into your mouth. It help you to relax and breathe more easily. A nebuliser delivers medicines into your lungs in a form that you breathe.

8472.Definicao: This is how genes pass on characteristics from your mum and dad to you. When red hair ‘runs in the family’, this means it has been passed on to you through your parents’ genes. Characteristics can also ‘jump’ generations, your parents may not have red hair, but maybe your granddad did! Certain diseases are also passed on from your parents. There are different kinds of inheritance – some kinds means you’re more likely to inherit a disease.

8473.Definicao: This is part of your digestive system. You have a large intestine (also called the colon) and a small intestine (duodenum, jejunum and ileum). They work together to squeeze food through to your bottom, absorbing liquid and goodness along the way.

8474.Definicao: A type of injection that is given into a muscle.

8475.Definicao: A type of injection that is given into the spaces between the bones in your spine.

8476.Definicao: A kind of dye that contains radioactivity so shows up on scans.

8477.Definicao: If a word ends in ‘-itis’, it means that a part of your body is inflamed. For example, cystitis means that your bladder is inflamed.

8478.Definicao: An IV (intravenous) drip allows you to get the nutrients your body needs into your system through your veins when you're unable to actually eat or drink. It's also a way of getting medicines into your system when you can’t eat or drink – some medicines also work better this way.

8480.Definicao: Doctors make a really small cut on your body but you won't feel anything because you'll be under anaesthetic. They use this cut to put a really tiny camera inside your body in a bendy tube. This allows them to find out what's going on inside you.

8481.Definicao: This is also called your colon and is where any water from your food is absorbed to form poo.

8482.Definicao: Medication taken to stimulate a bowel movement and relieve constipation. In other words, it helps you have a poo.

8483.Definicao: The part of your eye that lets you focus what you see so it is clear.

8484.Definicao: A type of cancer that affects your blood cells.

8485.Definicao: This is the space inside a tube. In medicine, it's usually used to refer to the inside of a tubular organ, like your intestines, or the inside of a tube to give medicine, like a central line.

8486.Definicao: You usually have two of these, on either side of your chest inside your ribcage. When you breathe in air, it travels down the windpipe through the bronchi, into your lungs. When you breathe in, your lungs expand, and when you breathe out, they go back to their normal size. Your lungs are full of little bags (alveoli) which remove oxygen from the air we breathe in, and put carbon dioxide into the air we breathe out.

8487.Definicao: This is part of the immune system. Lymphatic vessels drain lymph away from the body and back into the bloodstream.

8488.Definicao: This word is used to describe a disease or condition that gets worse at time goes by, or which spreads to other parts of the body.

8489.Definicao: This is your lower jaw bone that holds your bottom teeth in place and forms your chin.

8490.Definicao: The bones in the skull that form your upper jaw are called the maxilla.

8491.Definicao: These are the layers of tissue that cover your brain and spinal cord. If the meninges become inflamed, this is called meningitis.

8492.Definicao: The smallest part of a substance.

8493.Definicao: This is a sore patch inside your mouth. Mouth ulcers are really painful, and are made worse if you eat or drink something acidic like lemon squash. They can be treated using gels you can buy from your chemist.

8494.Definicao: A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan produces images of what's going on inside your body. It uses very strong magnetic fields (like a big magnet) and radio waves. An MRI scanner looks like a tunnel that you lie inside. It takes a while but you can watch a video or listen to music while you're in there, so it's not that as bad as it sounds. You do have to lie very still though, but it doesn't hurt at all.

8495.Definicao: The lining of many parts of the body, like your nose and mouth. They let out a fluid (mucus) that keeps everything moist.

8496.Definicao: A seroius illness that mainly affects children. Most children are immunised against mumps now, by the MMR jab, but children who have not been immunised are at risk.

8497.Definicao: We have lots of muscles in our body – some are very small, others are very big. Muscles work by contracting (squeezing tight) and relaxing to make things move.

8498.Definicao: A tube that is passed up your nose, and down your throat to your stomach. It’s used for draining off what’s in your stomach, or for feeding if you can’t swallow.

8499.Definicao: A nebulizer is a bit like an inhaler, but you wear a facemask. The machine blows some medicine into the facemask so you can breathe it in.

8500.Definicao: This is just another way of describing your brain and spinal cord and the nerves connected to it.. It works like a modem, sending signals around your body. It tells your brain when you touch something. If something's hot or cold, a signal zooms from your fingers up to your brain.

8501.Definicao: This is an eye condition where your eyes move about, usually from side to side. You can’t control this movement, it’s just something that happens.

8502.Definicao: Sometimes, when you've been sick, it can be difficult doing things like you used to. An occupational therapist is someone who will help you to get used to doing everyday things again - such as doing up your laces or getting on with your schoolwork.

8503.Definicao: This is sometimes called your foodpipe. When you've swallowed your food, it travels to your stomach through this tube. It works by squeezing rhythmically to push the food downwards.

8504.Definicao: This is where you'll go to have an operation (surgery).

8505.Definicao: Sometimes the doctors need to be able to get inside your body to make you sort out problems that you're experiencing. Most operations are carried out under an anaesthetic, which means you won't be awake or know what is happening.

8506.Definicao: This means your mouth. Some medicines have to be swallowed – these are called oral medicines.

8507.Definicao: The name of a dentist who specialises in straightening or moving teeth.

8508.Definicao: This is the study of bones. Doctors who operate on your bones are called orthopaedic surgeons.

8509.Definicao: A pacemaker gives off electrical signals if your heart isn’t beating regularly.

8510.Definicao: The study of children’s development and the diseases that affect children. A doctor who specialises in paediatrics is called a paediatrician.

8511.Definicao: Paracetamol helps to stop things from hurting. It can also make reduce swelling and stop you feeling as hot. You should only ever take paracetamol according to the instructions on the bottle.

8512.Definicao: The medical name for your kneecap.

8513.Definicao: This is a gland (a tiny organ) deep in your brain that makes lots of hormones (chemical messengers that turn on and off processes in the body.

8514.Definicao: This is a straw coloured liquid in your blood. All the blood cells float in it while the blood travels around your body.

8515.Definicao: These are the smallest types of blood cell, which helps make your blood clot when you cut yourself.

8516.Definicao: The period of time after a woman gives birth.

8518.Definicao: The term used to describe babies that are born before 38 weeks of a mother’s pregnancy.

8519.Definicao: Premedication or 'premed' is a special medicine that you are sometimes given before an operation (surgery). It's usually a liquid that you can drink and it helps to stop you worrying about the operation. Some types of pre-med help to dry up your mucus too.

8520.Definicao: A mark on the skin that is usually red and sore. It may also be itchy. Rashes happen if you’re allergic to something and goes away quite quickly. A rash can sometimes be a sign of disease too, such as measles.

8521.Definicao: Red blood cells carry oxygen from your lungs to cells around your body.

Traducoes.es: las células rojas de la sangre

8522.Definicao: If you’ve had a disease that has gone away for a while, and then it comes back, the doctors will say you’ve had a relapse.

8523.Definicao: If you’ve got a disease and it goes away, doctors will say that you’re in remission. It doesn’t mean that you’ve been cured, as the disease could come back (relapse).

8524.Definicao: This describes a person who has been successfully revived after they had previously stopped breathing of their heart had failed. This is generally done using cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR, see entry).

8525.Definicao: The layer on the back of your eyeball where pictures are converted into nerve signals which your brain understands.

8526.Definicao: Another name for German measles, an infectious disease that mainly affects children. Most children are immunised against rubella now, by the MMR jab, but children who have not been immunised are at risk. If a pregnant woman develops rubella, the baby can be born deaf and blind.

8527.Definicao: A mixture of water and salt, which is used to replace body fluids.

8528.Definicao: A crust that forms on your skin or a mucous membrane if you’ve been injured. It’s made up of clotted blood and pus.

8529.Definicao: The medical name for your shoulder blade.

8530.Definicao: A test that let the doctor look at the inside of part of your body. There are lots of different types of test, like a gastroscopy which involves your stomach and a cystoscopy which involves your bladder.

8531.Definicao: A way of making you very sleepy, usually before and during a test or procedure.

8532.Definicao: Seizures can seem very frightening, both for you and your friends and family. They make some people shake a lot and others stay very still. Your brain is a lot like a computer - it has lots of electricity flowing through it. Sometimes there's too much power and everything short-circuits - that's what happens when you have a seizure.

8533.Definicao: Another word for your brother or sister.

8534.Definicao: This is part of your intestines and is about six metres long. It's all coiled up inside your abdomen. The small bowel's job is to remove the goodness from your food so that it can be absorbed by your body.

8535.Definicao: When you want to sneeze, nothing will stop it! It’s a response to something irritating your nose or airway. When you sneeze, it’s important to catch it in a hankie or tissue.

8536.Definicao: If you breathe very noisily when you’re asleep, this is called snoring.

8537.Definicao: This is when one of your muscles contracts (squeezes) suddenly. Some types of spasms include hiccups and cramps.

8538.Definicao: A type of injection that is given under the skin.

8539.Definicao: If you have to apply a cream or ointment topically, that means you apply it to the surface of the skin that’s affected.

8540.Definicao: The medical word for your windpipe.

8541.Definicao: A growth of some kind. These days, it usually refers to a lump of cells that are growing in an uncontrolled way.

8542.Definicao: When two babies are born together, they’re twins. You can be an identical twin, which means the twins developed from the same egg, or non-identical twins which means that two eggs were fertilised at the same time.

8543.Definicao: A sore spot on your skin or mucous membrane, for instance, a mouth ulcer.

8544.Definicao: This scan uses sound waves instead of x-rays to show your insides. It's very like the scan most women have when they're pregnant.

8545.Definicao: These are blood vessels that carry blood back to the heart from the rest of your body. They are made up of different layers in a tube, like arteries, but are not as strong.

8546.Definicao: If you can’t breathe on your own after an operation or an accident, you may be put onto a ventilator. This is a machine that does your breathing for you.

8547.Definicao: The bones that make up your spine. Each vertebra has a hole in the middle so that the spinal cord can pass through it. You have 33 vertebrae in your spine.

8548.Definicao: X-rays allow the doctors to look inside your body, from the outside. The x-ray machine takes a picture, which helps them to see what's going on inside your body. The x-ray beams pass through soft tissue so looks black in the picture, but gets stopped by anything solid, such as bone, which shows white.
